titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI:15. We all went this Morning to Church, and heard prayers read by Mr Carr the Vicar, and the Sermon by Mr Lewis. The text, from 1. Peter IV.18. “And if the righteous scarcely be saved, where shall the ungodly, and the sinner appear?” The Sermon dull as usual. John was the whole day very unwell, and after Church so ill, that we sent for Dr Cook, the Apothecary at Brentford. He came and prescribed medecines both for John and Charles— I walked with George to Brentford and on the Windsor Road, an hour and a half before dinner— I answered this morning a Letter, received on Friday relating to the Seamen of the Monticello; who gave me so much occupation in June and July 1812— I was obliged to hunt up all the Letters that I then received and wrote upon the subject: and to recur to my journal of that time— In the Evening I wrote to the Secretary of State.

2. VI:45. Dr Cook visited the Children again this morning: they are both better, but George was taken suddenly unwell, at dinner, and this Evening was quite sick. He had taken a walk of five miles with me before dinner— We opened this morning two of the trunks from Ghent, and found the things without much damage. I was engaged the remainder of the day in making out my Account and the copies of it— Made up a packet for the Secy: of State, enclosing Mr Sumter’s Letter to Mr Crawford, and also a small Packet for my father, containing only Letters from Mrs Adams and Charles, and the Observer.

3. VI:15. Received this Morning, under a cover with a printed address of Hampshire Telegraph—C. S. Lefevre Esqr. M.P. and a written address under it. For his Excellency the American Ambassador now at London, a Newspaper, the Bath Journal of 11. September last. It contains advertisements of an oculist with a multitude of recommendatory certificates, and I suppose was sent to me from a motive of kindness, but I know not by whom— John continues still very unwell, and was again visited by Dr: Cook— I went to town in the Curricle, and on arriving at the Office in Charles Street, found a Mr Williams who came for a Passport, and offered to take any Letters or despatches for me— I went then to Mr King’s lodgings at the St. Paul’s Coffee-House, but he had been gone about an hour, for Liverpool, to embark for the United States.— After calling at the general Post-Office, and at the Bankers 69. Lombard Street, I went to the New-England Coffee-House, and left the despatches and Letters that I had ready, there, to be sent for Liverpool this Evening.
The keeper of the Coffee-house lent me several Boston Newspapers of the last week in August, and first in September— I next called upon Mr Beasley and left with him the account of the Brokers for the freight, landing &c of the three Trunks from Ostend, to settle. Thence I went to Lackington’s to enquire for the Books mentioned in my Fathers last Letter— Took only Tucker’s light of Nature pursued. It was by this time half past four O’Clock. I went to Vine-Street where the Coachman puts up his horses, and left the Curricle there, with directions to meet me in three quarters of an hour at Hyde Park Corner— I walked to the Office in Charles Street, and after taking the papers there walked to Hyde Park Corner. After waiting there about twenty minutes for the Coachman and Curricle, they came just as I was about taking a seat in a Stage that was passing by— I reached home just at seven O’Clock, before which time it is now completely dark.— Spent the Evening in reading the Boston Papers.

4. VI:15. John still continues so unwell that he could not return to school; but since the exhibition George has been desirous of going to the school to follow the studies during the day, and to come home to sleep at Night. After breakfast this morning I took Charles to school, and George went with us. Dr Nicholas said he had a few Scholars on that footing, who lodged at home— One of them was Wright, the Nephew of Sir James Wright, who lives in our neighbourhood— Another had been Fletcher, the performer at the late Exhibition; who during the last year of his attendance at school had lodged at home— He made no difference for it in the terms of schooling, but such Scholars boarded at his own table— George remained there, and from this day commences his attendance at the School.— Mrs. Adams took an hour’s walk with me before dinner. John made an attempt to write a Letter to his Grandfather in Latin. Charles had written one to him in French, yesterday— I wrote several Letters, and in the Evening made a first draft of a short one to Lord Bathurst— George came home in the Evening, much pleased with his school.— Fire in my writing room—first time this Season.

5. V:45. George went to school this morning after his usual reading—to be there precisely at seven O’Clock. It being a half holiday he came home at Noon— I walked with Mrs Adams to Ealing Grove, where there has been these four days an auction of furniture; it was just finishing when we reached the house— We met Dr: Nicholas there— The place itself is to be sold very soon. I afterwards walked an hour with George before dinner— To the Uxbridge Road.— The rest of the day I employed in writing to Mr Plumer.— Evening idle.

6. V:45. The morning was rainy and I sent George to school in the Curricle. John continues very unwell, and is threatened with a fever— I received and answered several Letters— Mr Amory paid us a visit. He goes next Monday with Mrs Amory for France. I rode in the Curricle to Twickenham Common to pay a visit to Mr and Mrs Dickason— They are gone to the isle of Wight and are not expected to return in less than a fortnight. I walked home from the tenth Mile Stone— Wrote part of a Letter this Evening to the Secretary of State.

7. VI: George rose so late that I postponed his reading until the Evening that he might reach school in time— The names being called over at seven O’Clock— I received several Letters; one of them from Messrs. Foxes and Hamilton, London; enclosing a Commission for R. W. Fox, as Consul of the United States, at Falmouth, which they request me to present for the approbation of this Government. I went into London with Mrs. Adams.— Mr Ogden called at the Office going this Evening to embark in the Packet at Falmouth— After having the copies completed of the necessary papers, I closed my Letter to Lord Bathurst, and left it with Mr Grubb to take to his office— I called at the foreign Office, and left with Mr Morier, Mr Fox’s Commission— I asked him whether the time for Mr Bagot’s departure was fixed: he believed not, but supposed it would be very soon— On returning to the office, I found there a Mr Shaw, who had already called upon me several times. He is a native of England, but has been upwards of thirty years settled in South-Carolina.— He asked my opinion, whether an Estate could be granted in America, to be held in fee by Citizens of the United States, in trust for a foreigner— He thought it could— But the English lawyers were of opinion it could not— I thought it depended upon the Statute Laws of the several States— He expressed a very strong desire to convey a small Estate in South-Carolina to Lord Lowther, son of the Earl of Lonsdale, with whom he was also very anxious to make me acquainted— He said that he was of a poor family, and the father of the Earl of Lonsdale had given him his education— He wished to transfer this Estate to Lord Lowther as a testimonial of his gratitude— And he finally said he would call upon me with Lord Lowther on Wednesday, when I told him I should again come to town. I went with Mrs Adams to one or two shops, and after leaving with Mr Grubb the papers for the Secretary of State to be despatched this Evening by Mr Ogden, we left the Office at five and reached home, at half past six O’Clock.— George read in the Evening.

8. VI: We went to Church this morning, without John, who is yet quite unwell.— Prayers were read by Mr Carr, and the Sermon was preached by Mr Lewis from Psalm 51. v. 3.— “My Sin is ever before me.” It was one of his better sort of discourses an exhortation to meditate upon our vices and faults, rather than upon our good qualities and actions— After Church, George invited two of his schoolmate Sheaffe and Thresher, to come and spend the day with him— They dined with us— Mr Shaw came from town with Lord Viscount Lowther to consult further about the Conveyance which Mr Shaw wishes to be made to his Lordship of an Estate in South-Carolina— Lord Lowther is going in a day or two to Paris— They will have some difficulty in executing their intentions. They were here about half an hour. I took a walk of five Miles before dinner, but the Evening was so cold that I could not pass it in my chamber nor of course employ it in writing. The day thus slipped insensibly away.— We visited Mrs: Von Harten, and also at Major Morison’s and Mr Copland’s at Gunnersbury.

9. V:30. For the first time this Season, there was a star yet visible when I rose this morning. I immediately roused George, but he had barely time for his morning reading, and to reach his school by seven o’clock. I wrote a Letter to my father, and it occupied the greatest part of the day. Rode out in the Curricle with Mrs Adams and John; we went upon the Uxbridge Road— We went to the ten Mile Stone from Tyburn, and returned by the same way and through Ealing— The weather was cold, and the wind boisterous and unpleasant— After returning home I walked an hour alone. In the Evening I wrote a short Letter to Mr Jackson at Paris.

10. V. As the Clock struck I left my bed— I am half an hour dressing, and at half past five I roused George— At six he began his French reading, which takes from half to three quarters of an hour— He has a mile to walk to School, and must be there at seven O’Clock. After writing a Letter to Mr Russell at Stockholm, I called and paid a visit to General Dumouriez. He began by asking me, if we were quarreling again with England, and asked what they meant by their proceedings with the Creek Indians— I said that one of their officers had been endeavouring to make mischief, by a pretended Treaty offensive and defensive with the Creek Indians; but that the Government here had disavowed his conduct to me— He asked if it was not such a disavoval, as that of 1755— I said that was what I could not tell— He thought we should not be long without another War with England; and that there would soon be a separation of the United States. As our population increased he said, with such an immense territory, it would be too large for one Government— I said that as our Government is federative, I did not see any necessity for a separation, which would be so contrary to the interests of us all. He said that mankind seldom pursued the system of their interest, and he thought our Union could not hold together long. He also thought we should soon be encroaching upon the Mines of New Mexico; and asked something about our establishment on the Columbia River. He spoke also of Canada, and the danger of the British possessions in North America, by their vicinity to the United States— Of the fur trade, and the diminution of the Indian hunting grounds. On all these Subjects he had some information; but it was all partial, and such as he had apparently imbibed from those with whom he converses concerning them here. In combating his prejudices, I did not expect to alter his opinions; nor would it that I know, have been of any use if it had— He passed to the subject of France, where he said every thing was dark and gloomy— He read me an extract of a Letter which he said he had just received, and which was from the Government here. It spoke of the Treaty of Peace just concluded between the allies and France— Mentioned the Conditions much as they are stated in the Newspapers. But it appeared that he had advised the taking of Calais and Dunkirk, by the English— The answer said that they had avoided asking for those places, for fear of exciting too much jealousy, but they were to have Ostend, and would fortify it so as to make it very strong— The General read to me also a Letter from the Duke of Wellington which he received a few days since—dated the 26th: of Sept: and he gave me the copy of his answer to it, dated 4. October, and written on the blank pages of the second sheet of the Duke’s letter— That was itself an answer to a previous Letter from Dumouriez, in which as he said he had reproached the Duke for the appointment of Fouché, as Minister to the king of France— The Duke says, that in prevailing upon the king to take Fouché, he had followed the opinions of all the allies who considered it as indispensably necessary. That when the allied armies advanced into France, the French Army, which still existed and a great part of the Nation were absolutely against the king— That four provinces were in open rebellion, and most of the rest, including the City of Paris, extremely cold.— That the allies themselves were more than indifferent about the Bourbons, and Prussia in particular absolutely adverse to their restoration— That the employment of Fouché neutralized a very great party against the king, and gained over great numbers to the royal Cause— That if he had not been employed, a great and terrible convulsion would have ensued. (Dumouriez said, il se trompe beaucoup là.) That Fouché might perhaps have done many
bad things, but not one half so many as his slanders laid to his charge— That he believed the king was satisfied with Fouché, but the Courtiers that vile, useless, and pernicious tribe, (Oh! pour cela said Dumouriez, il a bien raison) after the crisis was over, had besieged the king, and finally prevailed upon his too yielding temper.— That it was the party of the Princes which had consummated the mischief, and particularly the Duchess of Angouleme, who having arrived after the danger was over, could not be perswaded that it had existed.— (That Duchess of Angouleme said Dumouriez, nothing can beat it out of her head, that France is to be governed, comme au tems de St. Louis.) She, continued Wellington’s Letter, persuaded the king to the injudicious step of changing his Ministry, and I am sorry to add, says the Letter, in that transaction, the king treated with “mauvaise foi,” not only his own Ministry, but the allies by whom he had been restored to his throne— Eh bien, said Dumouriez after reading the Letter; you see that does not look like quiet times— Vous voyez que les termes ne sont pas menagéz là— Now read my answer—and he put it into my hands. The answer was full of flattering Compliments to the Duke, upon the wisdom of the course he had pursued; with great applause upon his invective against the Courtiers, and regrets that they had prevailed upon the bon Roi, to change the Ministry which the Duke in his wisdom had given him— (This is characteristic—for the Sentiments were diametrically opposite to those that the writer had just expressed to me in Conversation.) It proceeded to say, that what they were doing would certainly not finish the affairs of France— That there was a great and very unfounded expectation in public from the approaching assembly of the Legislative chambers— That they would begin with an apparent unanimity, and that very unanimity would be the greatest of deceptions. That upon some occasion, debates would very soon arise in which the metals would separate and they would be then found to be of the most discordant materials— That a reaction would sooner or later take place, which would oblige him the Duke to put on the harness again, as well as his venerable companion in arms (Blucher) and which would throw Europe again into a flame. That he wished the Duke, before Winter, would take care to get into his hands eight or ten fortresses, which he names—and among them, and most especially Calais and Dunkirk— So that in case of a new convulsion, forty or fifty thousand English families now in France might have places of refuge into which they could retire.— I told Dumouriez I did not think there was any danger like that— He said that the French Nation would need the greatest and most persevering patience— They were now suffering other nations to cut their nails, and draw their teeth, and were obliged to see it in quiet— It was necessary to wait until these defences should grow again, and Patience was precisely that which the French Nation wanted— I asked him what he thought of the Duke de Richelieu as prime Minister— He said the Duke de Richelieu had been these twenty years in Russia— He had been governor of Odessa, with perhaps sixty thousand Souls under him, and two thirds of them slaves— That it was said he had been a good Governor of a Province in a despotism; but to make him prime Minister of France, seemed to him like saying to a man, Sir, I have seen a very good Song, of your writing, have the goodness to write me a Tragedy— He said that he had many other Letters from France, and all painted the state of things in the most gloomy colours— As his dining hour was come I took leave of him, and he shewed me his library, where he has a good collection of Books— From his house I took a walk round through Acton, the Uxbridge road, and Ealing, home.— In the Evening I began a Letter to the Secretary of State— George dined at home.

11. V. After finishing the Letter to the Secretary of State, I went in the Curricle into London, and called to see the Spanish Ambassador, Count Fernan Nunez. He was at Brighton, but Mr Curtoys was at home— I spoke to him about the vessel, the William and Mary, taken last February by an English armed Brig, within the Spanish Jurisdiction; the case concerning which Messrs: Dickason and Nevett have written to me— They wished to obtain the Ambassador’s permission to enter an appeal from the decision of the Admiralty Court at Gibraltar, to prevent the distribution of the property— Curtoys said he had told Dickason and Nevett, and he still thought that the Ambassador could do nothing without Orders from his Court— I then asked if upon an application from me, he would write to his Court, and ask for orders—he said without doubt— I therefore left the Spanish Papers with him, and am to write a Note to the Ambassador— He told me that Miss Margaret Brown had been a few days since in town, and he had seen her— She was now with her Sister Mrs Keate at Eton— On arriving at the Office in Charles Street I found Mr Ingraham there from Plymouth. Mr Fox the Consul at Falmouth, has appointed his nephew Consular Agent at Plymouth, which Mr Ingraham thinks an encroachment upon his right— He had a Letter from Mr Pleasonton, of the Department of
State, to his father at New-York, saying that the President in reappointing Mr Fox as Consul at Falmouth, had expressly reserved the Consulate of Plymouth, as he understood for Mr Ingraham. I took the Letter and promised to write to Mr Fox, at Falmouth, on the subject— I called at the Seal Engraver Silvester’s, about the device; but he had it not yet to my fancy— Made up the packets for America, and left them with Mr Grubb to take to Mr Williams who was to go this day for Liverpool— Home at six O’Clock— A rainy ride— And an idle Evening.— While I was at the Office, the Clerk or partner of Smith the horse-dealer came, and after proposing to me to split the difference, about the sum that he had claimed of me, and that which I had agreed to pay, upon my refund agreed to take the money as I had offered it; I promised to send him the money.

12. V— Pio went into London, and by him for Mr Smith the Horse dealer which he paid, and took his receipt; which finishes a transaction that has given me some trouble. I wrote a Letter to Mr Fox at Falmouth concerning Mr Ingraham and the rest of the morning gave to this Journal. Walked an hour before dinner and dined with Mrs Adams at Major Morison’s at Gunnersbury. Dr. Nicholas, his son Frank, and two eldest daughters, Dr: and Mrs Goodenough, Mr and Mrs Von Harten, Mr Copland, a Mr Ommany, with Major, and Mrs Morison, Miss Blair, and another young Lady residing with them formed the Company. Mrs Von Harten is a native of Fairfield in Connecticut. Mr Ommany, asked me whether there was in America, a species of food that bore his name— I said there was in the Southern parts of the United States a species of food called Hominy which was very common— He said it had sometimes been mentioned to him as the derivation of his name. Major Morison is a Scotchman, with the national attachments in all their force.— There was music after dinner— The Miss Nicholas’s played on the Piano, and Mrs Morison sung. the Major was enchanted with the Scotch Songs— We came home about eleven. George had dined with Mr Barberi.

13. V. Between seven and eight this Morning Mr William Shaw of South Carolina, and Mr William Broadfoot of the same State, came out from London, and executed the Deeds for the conveyance of the Estate called Lowther, in Pendleton County S. Carolina in trust for William, Lord Viscount Lowther— There was an Indenture conveying the Estate in fee-simple from Mr Shaw, to Mr Broadfoot, which was executed by both of them, and a Deed Poll, executed by Mr Broadfoot alone, declaring the trust to be for Lord Lowther his heirs and Assigns. There were two copies of each deed— I read one copy of each, and at the request of Mr Shaw witnessed the Execution of them all. Richard Brant my Servant was the other witness. I promised Mr Shaw to go into London to prove them before the Lord Mayor— The Gentlemen were both so hurried that they declined staying to Breakfast— Mr Broadfoot was to go, at half past twelve for Liverpool. I wrote a Letter to Count Fernan Nunez, Duke of Montellano, on the subject of the American Vessel the William and Mary, upon the Papers furnished me by Messrs: Dickason and Nevett. I have purchased a pair of Pistols, for George and John to learn the practice of firing them; of their fencing Master, Mr Barberi— As a trial of them was to be made, I chose rather to make it myself than that it should be made by either of them— Barberi had been running some balls, for them— I asked him to load the Pistols, and said I would fire one of them myself. He mistook the quantity of the powder, and put in a full double charge— I fired the pistol at a tree in the Garden, at twenty paces distant, but did not hit it— The pistol flew out of my hand, and fell at least ten feet distant from me in a diagonal line to my left, and backwards. It wounded my hand and fingers in four places. A lesson of Caution for the children in the use of the Pistols which I hope will not be lost. Barberi afterwards fired the same pistol with half the same charge of powder, and it was still too much— The pistol did not fly from his hand, and the Ball hit the tree; but just on one side and about ten feet high from the ground— Notwithstanding the wounds in my hands, I made a fair copy of my Letter to the Spanish Ambassador. While at dinner I received a Letter from Mr Harris at St Petersburg, enclosing one from Messrs: Meyer and Bruxner, with a Bill of Lading, for all our effects which they have shipped on board the ship Ann, Captain Perkin, bound to London, their Account with me, and a Bill of Exchange, first and second, for the balance belonging to me, which was in their hands.— We went with all the children to a play, performed by a company of strolling players in a Barn at Hanwell— The performances were Raising the wind, and the Devil to pay, with a number of songs, and a duet of interlude. I have seen many far worse performers—but never so miserable a theatre— Though we all thought it very tedious, we stayed it out, and it was about eleven O’Clock when we came home. The Barn was much crowded, but with very low company. The children all slept at home.

14— V. On the fourteenth of November after the interval of an entire month, I am for the first time enabled to resume the pen. My whole course of life has been changed, and I am yet uncertain how far I shall be able to return to my occupations. Mrs Adams has kept short minutes of the occurrences from day to day, from which I shall endeavour to preserve unbroken the chain of this journal.
One of the wounds in my hand, festered in the Night, and was this morning quite sore. I wrote a few lines, but the principal hurt is on the fore finger of the right hand; and I must consequently drop the pen for some time. I went into London. The last time I had been at the office I received a Petition from a Seaman named Millard, an American, but who has been voluntarily in the British naval service— He is now a convict on board a hulk at Portsmouth under sentence of transportation; and petitions for my interference with the British Government to obtain his pardon upon condition that he shall return home to America. By his own Statement his only offence was while mate of a Store-ship, ordering some damaged Gun-powder to be thrown over-board. I took his petition this day to Mr Morier at the foreign Office, and asked him if any thing could be done for the man. He asked me to enclose the petition to him, and promised that enquiry should be made into the case. I accordingly sent him the petition. Mr T. M. Jones and Mr Ingraham called at the Office. I sent the Letter I had written to the Spanish Ambassador. Received several Letters from Boston and Quincy, with a collection of pamphlets upon the Trinitarian Controversy, now raging in Boston. They were brought by Mr Cary, the junior Minister at the Stone Chapel in Boston, who arrived at Liverpool in the New Packet; and is on his way to London, dying with a Consumption. I came home about six in the Evening. The children were all at home from School— Note to Mr Morier, asking an order for the admission of our baggage from Russia—

15. V.15. My hand is now so sore that I cannot write at-all. I am therefore obliged to devote almost my whole time to reading. One of my purposes in going to London yesterday was to accompany Mr Shaw to the Mansion house, to prove the Deeds of the Estate to be conveyed to Lord Lowther before the Lord Mayor.— But the Lord Mayor had appointed two O’Clock for the business, which not being known to me, I arrived in town too late to reach the mansion house at that hour. I offered Mr Shaw to go down there with him; and we might have been there before half-past two— But he thought it would be too late, the Lord Mayor having told him that he should be engaged elsewhere immediately after two. Mr Shaw therefore undertook to obtain the appointment of another day, and this day came out to inform me that the Lord Mayor would see us either to-morrow or on Tuesday at ten O’Clock in the Morning, or at 3 in the afternoon. He had waited for us yesterday until three O’Clock, with all his Servants in State Liveries &c &c—for he Mr Shaw had taken care that I should be received with due respect. I promised to call on Mr Shaw on Tuesday Morning, to go with him, and in time to be at the Mansion House at ten O’Clock. But I desired his to request the Lord Mayor to receive us entirely without ceremony, as I should wait upon him in my private capacity. I went to Church to the afternoon Service— The prayers were read by Mr Lewis; and the Sermon by Mr Warry. Mr Barberi, George’s fencing master, and his schoolmates Flexney and Chambré dined with us. They returned at 8 in the Evening with John and Charles to School. I read this day all the pamphlets which I received yesterday from Boston upon the Trinitarian Controversy.

16. V:15. I still continue to rise at my usual hour, and to hear George read before he goes to School. But I am now obliged to have the fire made in my Room by my Servant Antoine, and begin to rise by candle-light— My exercise this day was a walk round, through Gunnersbury, Acton and Ealing, and my employment was reading part of the first volume of Tucker’s Light of Nature— A large Piano Forte, purchased for my wife, was this day brought out from London, by Mr Barberi and Pio; who has been several days unwell with an abscess in his hand.— George finished reading the new Testament.

17. V. Went into London early this Morning and called upon Mr Shaw at his lodgings, N. 3. St: Albans Street. I found him just rising. Took him in the Carriage, and we went to the Mansion House, after calling at his Solicitor’s. N. 68 Chancery Lane, for the Papers— There were two Affidavit’s drawn up, stating the Circumstances of the Execution of the two Deeds, and that I was sworn, according to the form of my religious Profession— The Lord Mayor was in a Black Silk Judge’s Gown, and was going to hold a Court. His Secretary administered the Oath to me; and in the first instance offered me the Book. I observed that as the Affidavit expressed that I was sworn according to the form of my own religious Profession, it was not upon the Book, but with the lifted hand— I was so sworn accordingly— The Lord Mayor said he had never seen the Oath so taken before— The City Recorder, who was present, said he had seen one instance of it, in the time of Lord Mansfield— It was a Scotch Presbyterian, and the Clerk of the Court, not knowing the form of the Oath, Lord Mansfield, who was himself a Scotchman and acquainted with it, administered the Oath himself— Our Ceremony was over
in a very few minutes, and on quitting the Mansion house, Mr Shaw left me, having Lord Lowther’s Gig and Servant in attendance upon him— I called at the lodgings of Mr C. W. Apthorp, who had left at my Office, the Letters and pamphlets from America which I had found there on Saturday. They had been brought by Mr Cary, who came in the New Packet to Liverpool, and with whom Mr Apthorp was a fellow passenger. Mr Apthorp came down and spoke to me. He said that Mr Cary was on the way from Liverpool to London, but being very ill, travelled slowly, and would probably not arrive here in less than a fortnight— I called also at Mr T. M. Jones’s lodgings, but found that he was gone, last Evening for Birmingham. Went to the Office in Charles Street; and being unable to write walked to Newman Street, to call upon Mr West the Painter— He is absent from town, at the isle of Wight, and not expected to return for several weeks— I returned again to Charles Street, where Mr Shaw soon after called.— He had drawn up a Letter as from me to Lord Lowther, which he requested me to sign, assuring his Lordship in the most positive terms that the two Deeds which I had witnessed were perfectly valid and legal to convey to him in fee simple, the Estate of Lowther in South-Carolina— I declined signing this Letter, and told Mr Shaw, that I hoped both he and Lord Lowther had understood me as expressly stating that the legality of the Conveyance could be established only by a decision in the judicial Courts— That none such had to my knowledge taken place; and I could not presume to say what it would be— That it would only lead Lord Lowther into an error, if I should express an opinion that the conveyance was complete and legal, and he should rely upon it— I returned home about half past six in the Evening.— George began reading the Old Testament in French, this morning.

18. V:30. The day was employed almost entirely in reading Tucker’s Light of Nature—finished the first volume— I walked round through Ealing, Acton, and Gunnersbury—about five Miles— When I was just half way out, I was overtaken by a shower, which followed me the whole way home— A few minutes before reaching home, Mr Ingraham overtook me; left his Gig, and walked home with me— He brought out with him a packet of Letters, received at the Office, from Spain, and containing nothing but enclosures for Mr Erving. Mr Ingraham is very anxious about his own Consular appointment at Plymouth— I have written to Mr Fox at Falmouth, on the subject, but have not yet received his answer— Mr Ingraham declined staying to dinner, and returned to London.

19. V:15. I was prevented by the badness of the weather from walking before dinner, excepting a few turns in the garden. We had company to dinner—Dr Nicholas, his two oldest daughters and his Son Frank—Mr Copland; Major and Mrs Morison, Miss Blair and Miss Carnell, and Mr and Mrs O. Everett— I received a Letter from Mr Shaw, whom I had invited, with an excuse for not coming, and an apology, for having proposed to me to sign the paper, which I had declined.— Our company spent the Evening with us, and we had some Music— Major Morison was unwell after dinner— My own hand being crippled, and that of Pio, still more so, the Entertainment of the Company was not so well ordered, as I should have wished;—and there was one deficiency of which I was reminded by Major Morison’s indisposition, and of which no customs of any other Country than this would have inspired the thought— Began the second Volume of Tucker’s light of Nature; and read in a Volume of Shakespear, which George has here from the circulating Library, the Play of Pericles Prince of Tyre— I had never read it before, and believe that not one line of it was ever written by Shakespear— I think the same indeed of Titus Andronicus— Pericles however is like Ireland’sa thing of shreds and patches, from the Comedy of Errors and the Winter’s Tale, with here and there a scrap from other Plays.

20. V:30. Excepting a walk round through Ealing, Acton and Gunnersbury, I had no other occupation this day, than that of dispatching George to school after his morning reading, and plodding over Tucker’s light of Nature— Mr Grubb sent me out a packet containing a Letter from the Chevalier de Llaño, the Librarian of the king of Prussia, who wrote me two Letters before— He has now sent me two copies, one for President Madison, and one for myself of a small pamphlet which he has ventured to publish against Chateaubriand; and which he announces only as the introduction to a great and important work against the same author— This unfortunate Gentleman, who is certainly a man of learning, and of a reflecting mind, is tormented by the struggle between his ambition and his dependence, between his real principles and the sentiments which his situation compels him to profess. He is a republican and if at all a Christian, an anti-catholic; and he cannot hold his peace— He must write, and must publish, free doctrines, religious and political; but he must at the same time profess veneration for the Pope, and the Princes of the house of Bourbon— So he adds manuscript Notes; that Mr Madison and I may not misunderstand him, or give too much credit to his courtly compliments— He is a Spaniard, writing of course a stiff and aukward sort of French, and must yet break
his lance against Chateaubriand, who is indeed a mere pompous sophist, but whose charm is altogether in his style. Llano will make a poor hand of his undertaking, and will probably finish by ruining himself.

21. V:30. When I was in London last Saturday, Mr Nevett of the house of Thomas Dickason and Co: called at the Office in Charles Street and enquired whether I had applied to the Spanish Ambassador concerning the case of the William and Mary— I told him of the Conversation that I had a few days before had with Mr Curtoys, and shewed him the Letter that I had prepared and then sent to the Spanish Ambassador— I had taken into town the Bill of Exchange from Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner, upon John Mitchell & Co: to get it accepted. I was enquiring where Mr Mitchell lived of Mr Nevett, and he offered to take the Bill and have it presented— He has since sent it back to me accepted; and I received his note on going into town this morning— The Bill is payable the 15/18 December.— Mr T. W. Fox of Plymouth called at the Office. His Uncle had appointed him Vice-Consul at Plymouth— I mentioned to him what I had written to his uncle upon the subject; and that I thought it would not be proper to suspend Mr Ingraham’s agency there for a few Months, when there was reason to believe it to be the intention of the President of the United States to appoint Mr Ingraham Consul for Plymouth at the next Session of the Senate. Mr Fox said that his uncle and himself would readily abide by my opinion, and that he would accordingly forbear to act in the Consular capacity.— I called at Mr Shaw’s lodgings, where he had been in St: Albans Street, but found he had left the house— As I was walking in Pall-Mall, I met an old acquaintance, Mr Justinian Casamajor; who was in America with Mr Rose, and whom I had known before, with Lord Carysfort at Berlin. I enquired after his brother Lewis, who was likewise with Mr Rose in America— He told me that he was now here, lately returned from Lisbon, where he has been Secretary of Embassy with Mr Canning. The whole of that Embassy, he told me had been recalled, and Mr Canning was now living as a private Gentleman in the neighbourhood of Lisbon— Mr J. Casamajor himself has no employment under the Government. I came home about six O’Clock— General Dumouriez had paid us a visit.

22. VI: Attended church, morning and afternoon— The prayers of both services were read by Mr Lewis— The Sermon of the forenoon was preached by Mr Carr of Brighton, son of the Rector of the Parish of Ealing.— That of the afternoon by Mr Warry— After the Evening service I walked through Brentford home— Mr Grubb came out and dined with us, with his Son Edward, a boy about seven years old. George’s Schoolmates Daniel, and Hamilton, also dined with us; and our sons John and Charles, who in the Evening returned with them to school.

23. V:30. Mr: Grubb and his Son, spent the Night here, and returned to London early this Morning— The weather was so bad the whole day, that I only found half an hour before dinner to walk as far as Brentford.— I read in the Light of Nature all day— Finished the second, and began upon the third Volume. The incessant reading to which by losing the use of my right hand I have been reduced, has produced an inflammation in my left eye, which was noticed the day before yesterday by my wife, but to which I have myself paid no attention, until this Evening on going to bed I observed that it was considerably blood-shod. My hand has been slowly healing, and I expected to have been able to recommence to-morrow my ordinary course of occupations, and to have employed the usual portion of my time in writing.— Oh! blindness to the future!

24. V:15. I Rose this morning at the usual hour, and heard George as usual read five chapters in the French Bible, comparing it as he read, with the Latin Bible— Then changed the Books, and read one Chapter of the French to him— After he was gone to school, I continued reading until breakfast time— But my eye was already much inflamed and very painful— From this time I was obliged to renounce both writing and reading— Dr: Cook, a Surgeon and Apothecary of Brentford who attends the family, being here to visit Pio, whose hand is very bad, saw my eye, and advised me to diet and physic, to both of which I accordingly resorted.— Notwithstanding which the inflammation and swelling continued rapidly increasing, the whole day.— Mrs Adams read Tucker’s Light of Nature to me, great part of the day— The weather was fair; but I was not able to walk out; and kept the house— Went early in the Evening to bed.

25. George’s reading is necessarily suspended— I had a Night entirely sleepless; the inflammation and swelling of my eye continuing to increase, attended with severe and almost continual pain— This morning I could scarcely open the eye, and could not bear the light of day upon it— I was still in bed when Dr Cook called here, about ten in the Morning— He expressed his opinion that it was the Egyption Opthalmia, with a purulent discharge of acrimonious matter, and intimated the opinion that the vision itself was in imminent danger. I had better hopes, and told him that I had once before, between five and six years since had a very similar attack, the course of which
I described to him— He still adhered to his opinion, and advised an immediate application of leaches— He said however that he wished me not to be alarmed. I was however so averse to the use of leaches that he consented to wait a day or two longer to see if the inflammation would not subside without them— We tried the effect of physic, diet, or rather almost total abstinence; a hot foot-bath, and elder flower tea— I rose about Noon, and returned to bed early in the Evening. Mr Grubb sent me out last Evening four Letters— One from Mr Jackson, our Chargé d’Affairs at Paris, enclosing one from Genl: La Fayette— He sends me a pamphlet, containing the proceedings of the two Chambers, after the abdication of Napoleon; and until the return of Louis 18 with the allied armies. The General has returned to his retirement at La Grange;—and expects to remain there in obscurity. The other Letters were from Mr C. W. Apthorp, Mr Richard Vigor, and Mr James Williams— Mr Apthorp’s letter was to inform me, that Mr Cary died at Royston, on the way from Liverpool to London, last Sunday, the 22d: Mr Vigor, writes from Bristol and is one of the Candidates for the appointment of Consul of the U. S. at that Port, instead of Mr Elias Van der Horst, formerly the Consul, but who declines the re-appointment. Mr Williams took a Passport from me for the United States, and some despatches— He met with some difficulty for want of a Passport from the Alien Office, about sailing from Liverpool, but was finally permitted to go— My wife read me all these Letters; and put them on file. It is impossible for me to think of answering any of them at present.

26. X.— I rose about ten, this Morning, and the Doctor, who soon afterwards came, thought the inflammation of my eye had considerably subsided since yesterday, and hoped it would pass off without making the application of the leaches or of a blister necessary. But the latter part of his day, the inflammation returned with double violence— The pain became intensely severe, and almost without interval. The physic the foot-bath and the elder flower tea were repeated, and the abstinence continued apparently without effect I suffered so much that I could not even listen to my wife’s reading.— After George came home from School, we sent him to London, to procure a Candlestick with a shade— He brought one out, but it was not prepared with the green silk, and otherwise did not suit. We determined to change it for another— A pair of branches— Mr Grubb sent me out a Note from Mr Coffin, giving notice of his intention to go in a few days, for Liverpool and the United States, and offering to take Letters— Also a Letter from Mr Shaler, at Algiers, dated 28 July, giving an Account of the Peace lately made there by him and Commodore Decatur, and some good information concerning that Country. The Letter was forwarded by Messrs: Baring Brothers— Also a Card from Mr Chester, who had been at the Office in Charles Street, with information that the Queen was to hold a drawing room this day, and would then receive me. The drawing Room is on account of the two Austrian Archdukes John and Lewis, who have just arrived in England, where they are to pass several Months; and also for the reception of the new Austrian Ambassador, Prince Esterhazy who has arrived with the Princes— Mr Grubb informed Mr Chester of the illness, which rendered it impossible for me to attend upon the Queen this day, of which Mr Chester promised to make his Report to Her Majesty. Mr Chester enquired if I had received from Mr Neumann, the Austrian Chargé d’Affairs, a notification that the Archdukes would this day receive the foreign Ministers— I had not, and if I had, must have made the same excuse as, to the Queen. When George returned from town, Mr Grubb sent me by him two Notes just received from Lord Bathurst— The first dated on the 20th: inst. unsigned, and relating to the Petition of Millard— He states that it had been found upon due enquiry that the crime of which the Prisoner was convicted was of such a Nature that Lord Sidmouth could not consistently with his public Duty, advise the Prince Regent to extend the Royal Mercy to the said Millard.— The second Note is dated on the 25th: instant—is signed, and contains an elaborate answer of eighteen folio pages to the remonstrances made by the Secretary of State, Mr Monroe, and renewed by me here, against the carrying away of Negro Slaves, by the British Admirals, in violation of the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent. It is a positive and peremptory refusal of all satisfaction. I can reply nothing to it now; and probably shall not reply without fresh instructions from the Secretary of State.

27. The pain and inflammation of my eye was so excessive that I had not a moment of sleep the whole Night through; and it produced some feverish symptoms from which I had hitherto been exempt— My wife, and her chambermaid Lucy Hauel, were up with me the whole Night. They passed it in the drawing-room—the Bed chamber being too cold— This day however a fire was made in it. When the Doctor came he reverted again to his idea of the Egyptian Opthalima, and urged the application of Leaches immediately as indispensible. I accordingly consented and about noon he brought and applied six of them to the swelling round the lower eye-lid— Two of them, would not effectually bite, but dropped off within five minutes— The other four bit keenly, and were nearly an hour, upon my face— After they dropped off the wounds they had made were kept bleeding with continual fomentations of warm water between four and five hours— My wife’s kind attention was incessant; but the fatigue, and anxiety, and alarm, together with the hideous aspect of the operation of the leaches almost overpowered her strength. The
bleeding by the leaches was so copious, that it very much reduced the inflammation, and gave me considerable momentary relief— I rose about six in the Evening; and sat up without leaving my Bed chamber, about three hours.— But on returning to bed; the pain returned in all its sharpness. The swelling continued to increase; and the inflammation returned— I apprehended that the leaches had been of little service, and waited for the trial to-morrow of a blister.— My Son John too, though still at school, is very unwell— I sent the Coachman this day to London, with the Note, received yesterday from Lord Bathurst, concerning the carrying away of the Negro Slaves. My wife enclosed it to Mr Grubb, with a request to him to make a copy of it to send to the Secretary of State— Mr Grubb sent me out two Letters— One, from Mr Maury at Liverpool; and the other from Messrs: Alexander Glennie, Son and Co: Agents for the Navy Department of the United States at London— These Gentlemen inform me, that Mr Richard M’Call, Navy Agent of the United States at Gibraltar, had drawn Bills upon them to supply the wants of the American Squadron in the Mediterranean, beyond the amount of the funds remitted to them by the Navy Department— They intimate that they cannot make any advances, and call upon me to give them an order upon the Agent of the Treasury to supply them with funds. I received also a Note from Mr William Vaughan, requesting to lend him, if I have it, the last Edition of Morse’s Geography, and any other statistical details concerning the United States, for the use of Dr Rees, in the work which he is now publishing— I must at present take every thing ad referendum.

28. Mrs: Brooks, the Cook, and Margaret Wedge the house maid, watched for me, the whole Night in the Drawing-Room. I did not call them once, the whole Night through; but I had a totally sleepless and extremely painful Night. The inflammation and swelling round my eye continued to increase, and this day was so great that I could scarcely anticipate how it would end. I had scarcely taken for five days any food, and now with much weakness and inanition had some, though no considerable fever. There is a discharge of a watery humour from the eye, the obstruction of which appears to be the cause of the inflammation.— It becomes mucous, purulent and glutinous; and the swelling round the eye having almost entirely closed it, the discharge has been consequently still more obstructed— Yesterday the eye was often washed with warm milk and water, and a small syringe was used to wash the Ball— This was found too powerful for the eye in its present state to bear— This day it has been frequently bathed with a small spunge, and the eye-lashes frequently anointed with lard, by a camels hair brush passed over them— This enabled me to keep the eye open as much as the swelling would admit— Until this expedient was resorted to the eye was almost constantly closed by the glutinous humour which fastened down the upper eye-lashes, upon the lower eye-lid— About seven this Morning I waked my wife, and requested her, to send earlier for Dr Cook, than the hour of his usual visit— I thought he would find it necessary to apply more leaches, and I was myself desirous of trying the effect of a blister— When he came he did not recommend any more leaches, but agreed to send the blister— I rose about one O’Clock afternoon, and it was then applied under my left ear— The Doctor, who has found that the Cornea, of the eye has not been affected, and that the Ball is less blood shod, since the application of the leaches, has better hopes than before; while my own concern is this day greater than it had yet been. The chamber was kept all day as dark as could be; to see to move in it. My eye could not endure the feeblest gleam of light— The blister took but slight effect; and was almost imperceptible to me, owing to the extremity of pain in the eye— The children came home from School— John very unwell with a slow fever. In the Evening before I went to bed the watery discharge from my eye seemed to be more free than it had been before— I went to bed about eight in the Evening, and the pain soon after became so violent, that I was nearly delirious— It seemed to me as if four hooks, were tearing that side of my face into four quarters— After being about an hour in that state, the pain abated considerably; the watery humour, dropped freely and continually from the eye; the extreme swelling apparently subsided; and I could perceptibly open the eye wider than I had been able for two days— One abscess had found an opening at the corner of the eye-lid next the nose, and a thick purulent matter oozed out slowly from it— Nothing this day from Mr Grubb— I received two Letters— One from Mr Shaw of South-Carolina dated N. 3. St: Albans Street, informing me that he has concluded not to go to Liverpool; but to sail for Charleston, from London. The other from a Mr Ingersoll, for whom I forwarded last Sumer a Letter to J. Ingersoll of Philadelphia. He writes to enquire if I have received an answer.

29. My wife and Lucy Hauel were up with me again the whole Night, and incessantly employed in giving me assistance— I had no sleep. The discharge from my eye, not only of the lacrymal humour, but of the purulent matter was continual, and required every half hour, and oftener, that the eye should be washed with the warm sponge, and the eye-lashes anointed with the larded Camel’s hair-pencil— The idea that the crisis of the disease was past, and the relief from pain by the copious discharge from the eye, and gradual abatement of the inflammation and swelling, eased at once in a great degree my body and mind— The Blister under my ear dropped off of itself, about five O’Clock this Morning— Dr Cook came about eleven— He had been suddenly called to the Coachman of our next door Neighbour
Mrs Fisher, whose horses ran away with the Carriage, and the Coachman being thrown down in the attempt to stop them, the Carriage wheels went over him, broke several of his bones, and left him nearly dead— The Doctor’s visit to me was very short— I rose about noon, but kept confined the whole day, to my warm and dark bed-chamber— We expected that Mr Grubb would have come out, as he had told George that he intended; but he did not come— John Newman, Captain of Dr Nicholas’s School, and Slack, another of the Scholars dined here with the family— Charles returned to school with them; but John was too ill with his fever and remains at home— We had been invited to dine next Thursday with Mr: and Mrs Von Harten; but as it will be impossible for me to go out, we sent George there with an excuse. Mrs Adams was quite unwell the whole of this day; and in the Evening, fainted away in the drawing-Room, after tea.

30. My wife had a pretty good Night’s rest, and I slept, part of the Night myself.— I rose about ten O’Clock this morning; and as the swelling and inflammation of my eye, continues to subside, I removed, from the Bed Chamber, into my wife’s dressing Room, where a fire was made and which was completely darkened.— My greatest evil here, now was the tediousness of the time, as I could not bear even light enough to hear reading to me— I paced the chamber, and slept a little; and had my blister dressed, and my eye frequently sponged and penciled, and took from four hours to four hours, the Doctor’s draughts, and thus waded through the day— It was now that I knew how to estimate the blessing of eye-sight, and the wretchedness of being bereft of it— Now too I had occasion for the tribute of gratitude to the gracious being, who in this trial has mercifully preserved my Vision— We sent the Coachman into town with the Curricle, to bring out Mr Grubb, whom I wanted to answer some of the Letters lately received, which admit of no delay— Mr Grubb however had left the Office before the Coachman arrived there; and he accordingly returned home without him— I received this Morning a Note from Mr Grubb, written on Saturday Evening— It should have come yesterday Morning— It enclosed the Note from Lord Bathurst about the Negroes, and the copy of it, made by Mr Grubb.— Also a Note from Mr Morier, written on Friday the 27th: requesting me to call on him at the Foreign-Office the next day, or any other day that would suit me, at two O’Clock— Mr Grubb’s Note however mentioned that a Messenger from Mr Morier’s Office, had been that day, to say that he was taken very ill; and could not attend to any business.— John continues quite ill with his fever, which is intermitting; coming on every day about noon, and continuing until 7 or 8 in the Evening.

31. The favourable symptoms in my eye, the abatement of the swelling and inflammation, and the discharge of the lacrymal humour, and purulent matter still continue— I was this day able to shave myself; the first time for eight days, and I could bear a little more light than yesterday. I rose about ten this morning and passed the day again in the dressing chamber— Received this morning a Note from Mr Grubb, dated yesterday, enclosing a Note from Lord Bathurst in answer to the representation I had some time since made, concerning the taking and carrying away of eleven Slaves belonging to a Mr Downman, by a British Officer, with the violation of a flag of truce— This Answer is altogether unsatisfactory. Mr Grubb sent also a Letter received from Mr R. W. Fox of Falmouth, with information that the Lorenzo, a Vessel from London for New-York, by which I had sent dispatches, had put into that Port, damaged.— We sent the Coachman again with the Curricle into town, for Mr Grubb, but he came out in the Stage— The Coachman returned with a Hare and brace of Partridges which Mr Grubb had received from France, and presented to Mrs Adams. A Candlestick with a pair of branches shaded came out also by the Stage.— I dictated and Mr Grubb wrote, an answer to the Letter of the 26th. instant from Messrs: Alexander Glennie, Son and Co.

Day. The first half of the Month I rose generally about five— It was then still daylight by the time when I had roused up George— He read to me five chapters of the Bible; and I one chapter to him— The French Bible of Saci; comparing it, with the Greek New Testament, and afterwards with the Latin Vulgate Old Testament. George then went to school, and I wrote in this Journal, and read the newspapers until about ten when we breakfasted— From eleven till four or half past four, I wrote Letters, or read except when I went into town—which was about twice a week. From four to six was my time for walking— At six we dined— I passed an hour or two in my chamber after dinner, again reading or writing. Then an hour with my wife and George, who returns every Evening from school— And about ten in the Evening was the hour of my retiring to bed— The greatest part of my time was thus devoted to writing, which a great and increasing Correspondence rendered necessary, but which by the will of Heaven had become very painful and difficult to me— My Life however was industrious, and was almost incessantly occupied with the discharge of my duties. All this system however was disconcerted, and for the time destroyed, by the accident which befell me on the 13th. of this Month. My right hand was wounded, and for ten days I could not write— I dedicated all my time to reading and brought on the inflammation in my eyes which has nearly made me blind—for the last week reading and writing have both been out of the question— A Sick chamber, and great part of the time a sick bed have been my lot. My only occupation has been to suffer—to seek for remedies, and to pray for recovery or for resignation— I humbly hope at the end of the next Month, to have a more cheering account to give.
